## Population Data

The data set shows the political stability estimate of the country each year.


```{r politicalStabilityEstimateByCountry, echo=FALSE, message=FALSE, warning=FALSE, paged.print=FALSE}

library(readr)
populationData <- read_csv("WGI2popDevIneqPovRegimeConflict1V2.csv")
populationVariables <- c("country", "iso3c", "date","population","populationCategory5")
populationData <- populationData[populationVariables]


# data by country
# country = x
x <- populationData[populationData$country == "Burundi",]
x

```

## Population trend

The plot shows the trends of stabilization and destabilization for the each country. 

```{r Political Stability Plot, echo=FALSE, fig.cap="Political Stability Trend", message=FALSE, warning=FALSE, paged.print=FALSE}
library(ggplot2)
populationTrend <- ggplot(data=x, aes(x=date, y=population)) +
  geom_line()+
  geom_point() +
  geom_hline(yintercept=0.0, color = "red", size = 1.25) +
   geom_hline(yintercept=1.0, linetype="dashed", color = "red", size = 1) +
   geom_hline(yintercept=-1.0, linetype="dashed", color = "red", size = 1) +
  ylim(0, 100000000) + 
  xlab("Year") +
  ylab("Population Trend")

plot(populationTrend)

# To save the figure:
# png("populationTrend.png")
# 
# plot(populationTrend)
# 
# dev.off()

```
